abstract.p: Letter by Peter Flynn responds to June 15 article on uninterruptrible power surge protection for computers; says article was correct in stating that the devices offer higher-quality surge protection than simple power strip

block.p: The letter about Uninterruptible Power Supplies (''Surge Protection,'' Incoming, June 15) was correct to assert that the devices offer higher-quality surge protection than a simple power strip. Some even include an offer to replace any equipment damaged by lightning while attached to the U.P.S.

The letter about Uninterruptible Power Supplies (''Surge Protection,'' Incoming, June 15) was correct to assert that the devices offer higher-quality surge protection than a simple power strip. Some even include an offer to replace any equipment damaged by lightning while attached to the U.P.S.

But the U.P.S. device's battery rarely comes into play for surge protection; most devices can lower the voltage to a safe level rather than switching to battery power. The advantage of a U.P.S. device is that when voltage drops below usable levels, as in a brownout or blackout, your computer will remain running for a few minutes. With some devices, that period allows files to be saved automatically before the computer loses power. My U.P.S. device has been working beautifully for more than a year and has protected my computer from many a power disruption since I bought it.
